head.title: Where May Has Married December and the Mix Is Just Right

abstract.p: Traditional Paris bistros Le Martel and L'Auvergne Gourmande have been freshened up; photos (S)

block.p: Traditional French bistros are flirting with contemporary design. The point is not to veer too far from the authentic atmosphere and floor plan (a bistro is a restaurant with a counter where you can simply have a drink). Two such places, Le Martel and L'Auvergne Gourmande, have successfully freshened up -- attracting a younger set without losing the old one.

A fashion and design crowd now gathers at Le Martel in the offbeat neighborhood of the 10th Arrondissement, just north of the Marais. Lorenzo Alati, 36, director for Benetton in France, bought the bistro, which is downstairs from his apartment, and asked an architect, Antonio Virga, to streamline the original features with off-white walls, hip graphics, dark wood furniture and a collection of contemporary black and white photographs. Artists who stop by are invited to decorate a wall mirror, above right.
